none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, May 22, 1882
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, May 22, 1882
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 12 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Bonham May 22 - 1882,
My Dear Professor;

Your welcome
letter recd some days ago. &
I embrace my first leisure
moment to reply. Wednesday,
Thursday & Friday of last week
were occupied by our last
"Monthly Examination". This morning
we enter the list on our "home
stretch". How I dread it!
These miserable public examinations
& public parades, where you
must do a thing every year
to show the public that you can
do it - "Who will deliver me
from this way of death!"

Your information - as to time
& place of meeting of Teachers
Association is Correct.
I do trust you will go.
The A & M. C has never been
represented in that body
but once - You remember
time, place & circumstances.

**Letter Transcription Analysis: A Deep Dive**

Okay, here we go. The task is to transcribe this handwritten letter, and I need to be as accurate as possible. First, the date and location are at the top: "Bonham May 22 - 1882."  That's straightforward. Then comes the salutation: "My Dear Professor," – a comma, not a semicolon! I'm making a mental note because I need to be exact here.

Now, into the body of the letter.  The initial phrases are: "Your welcome letter recd some days ago. & I embrace my first leisure moment to reply." The word "recd" looks like an abbreviation for "received." Then, "Wednesday, Thursday & Friday of last week were occupied by our last 'Monthly Examination'." Okay, jotting that down. Now we have something more interesting: "This morning we enter the list on our 'home stretch'." I need to look closely at that word "list". The context of "home stretch" suggests it’s a racing metaphor, so perhaps "enter the lists"? But the handwriting... it looks more like "list."  I'll transcribe it as "list" for now but revisit this. 

The author then laments, "How I dread it! These miserable public examinations & public parades, where you must do a thing every year to show the public that you can do it - " Now, this is where it gets interesting:  "Who will deliver me from this way of death!" This is a biblical quote, but the writer has changed "body" to "way". The original quote is "body". That looks like "way". Let’s analyze this.  I need to be certain about the transcription. The word begins with a letter. It's either "b" (as in "body") or "w". It looks like the "w" in "week" (line 7). The context of "way of death!" is strange. There's a slight possibility this is a misquote. Let's look again. The 'w' in "will", "welcome", and "week" is consistent with the initial letter here, so it is the letter "w", not "b". So I will use the word, "way".

Next, "Your information - as to time & place of meeting of Teachers Association is Correct." The word "Correct" is capitalized. Okay.  The writer goes on to say, "I do trust you will go. The A & M. C has never been represented in that body but once - You remember time, place & circumstances." Note the period after "M" in "A & M. C". I'm making sure to be precise and include all the punctuation. Also, "A & M. C" likely refers to the Agricultural and Mechanical College. So this is historical context to consider. I've re-checked every line, especially the words that are less clear. I will be sure to capture the visual layout by using line breaks. The transcription is ready!

[Header]

[1882, May 22]          2

If private axes can be kept
out of the Association, I see
no reason why it may not
be made an important
factor in our educational
enterprises. I would state
by way of parenthesis - that
I have consented to prepare &
read a paper before the
Association on the subject
of "Reading the Bible in Public
Schools". On investigation, I
find the subject one of
too grave a responsibility
to admit of embellishment.
Our Session Closes here on 21st
June - same time of your close.
It does seem that Texas ought
to furnish some one who would
be willing to perform the
labor of preparing & delivering
your Annual Address.
Men who expect to rise in the
world must be willing to
perform mental drudgery -

**Transcription Analysis and Output** Okay, so I've got this handwritten document, and my task is to produce a transcription. Let's break this down systematically. First, I need to analyze the image. The top right says "[1882, May 22] 2" in pencil. That seems to be an archival date and a page number, and I'll keep that information in mind. The ink is purple, and the handwriting is cursive, definitely English. From the context and what I can make out, it looks like it's likely a letter dealing with an educational association, possibly in Texas. It’s moderately legible – a bit scrawly, but manageable. Next, I'll do a line-by-line transcription, being careful to preserve the formatting. I'm noting the header: `[1882, May 22] 2` – that gives us some temporal context. Here's my transcription: ```html

If private axes can be kept
out of the Association, I see
no reason why it may not
be made an important
factor in our educational
enterprises. I would state
by way of parenthesis - that
I have consented to prepare &
read a paper before the
Association on the subject
of "Reading the Bible in Public
Schools". On investigation, I
find the subject one of
too grave a responsibility
to admit of embellishment.
Our Session Closes here on 21st
June - same time of your close.
It does seem that Texas ought
to furnish some one who would
be willing to perform the
labor of preparing & delivering
your Annual Address.
Men who expect to rise in the
world must be willing to
perform mental drudgery -

``` I checked my HTML tags and made sure I am staying within the set of allowed tags. I reviewed specific words, paying close attention to potentially ambiguous characters. I've gone back and double-checked several words: "axes," "out," "enterprises," "consented," "admit," "embellishment," "Session," "Closes," "Texas," and the ampersand. The final output is formatted with the header at the top, a line break for the date and a space before the page number. I've ensured to preserve line breaks and spacing. The writing is clear, and the context is preserved through the text. I am very confident with this.

[Header]

[1883, May 22]
3

I was not aware of his last
feat until I recd your letter.
He is certainly a weird
apotheosis of deadbeatism.
Will he get a place in the
University after his book
on sheep culture in Asia?
Gov. Brown must be a "scholar
& a gentleman" – By the by, what
do you think now of the
outlook & outcome of the
University? – I see it suggested
that a faculty will be elected
in July next. I know not
what foundation there may
be for the surmise.
Recent events at W. M. C.,
make me timid & I am
yet undecided whether
I shall ask for a place
in the University or not.
Cooper is being coached
at Yale for the Chair of
Ancient Languages & Col Ashbel
Smith is a strong Yale Man.

**Transcription Analysis and Refinement** Okay, here's what I've got. I'm looking at a handwritten document, and my task is to meticulously transcribe it. First, I need to analyze the image. The top right corner has "[1883, May 22] 3" written in pencil, which I'll keep in mind. The main body of text is cursive in purple ink; I need to make sure I get every line right. I'm approaching this line by line. I start with the header, `[1883, May 22]` and then the number `3`. The first line is "I was not aware of his last". Then "feat until I recd your letter." I see an abbreviation, "recd" for "received," which I will make sure to note. "He is certainly a weird". "apotheosis of deadbeatism." That's a fascinating term; I'll transcribe it precisely. "Will he get a place in the" and "University after his book." I want to note the capitalization here because it might indicate something specific. It is "on sheep culture in Asia?". "Gov. Brown must be a 'scholar" I note this, and then "& a gentleman". - By the by, what" followed by "do you think now of the". Then "outlook & outcome of the". Then "University? - I see it suggested". This is followed by "that a faculty will be elected" followed by "in July next. I know not" followed by "what foundation there may" followed by "be for the surmise." There are "Recent events at W M C,". Now "make me timid & I am" and "yet undecided whether" and "I shall ask for a place" and "in the University or not." "Cooper is being coached" and "at Yale for the Chair of". "Ancient Languages & Col Ashbel" and "Smith is a strong Yale Man." I need to go back and refine. "aware" – that looks fine. "recd" – yes, that's clear. "certainly" and "weird" – readable. "apotheosis" and "deadbeatism" – those words are clear. "University" – capitalized. "sheep culture" – spot on. "Gov. Brown" – abbreviated. "gentleman" – quoted with an ampersand, "By the by" is just a phrase, nothing too special. "University" capitalized again. "suggested" – a little hurried, but readable. "foundation" – slightly squashed, but there. "surmise" – it's all good. "W M C" – ah, this could be tricky, it looks like a W. Here is where the history knowledge comes in: It is likely `W M C` since the history is likely a good fit with Texas and the founding of UT. The word is `timid`. It is `undecided`. `University`. `Cooper`. `Yale`. `Chair`. It is `Col Ashbel`. It is `Yale`. The trickiest part is `W M C` It looks like a `W` but could easily be a `U` in that cursive. But contextually, I think the letters match and there is a "W". I need to be as faithful as possible to the shape and context. Is it `W. M. C.` with dots? The crop is not super clear but a faint mark seems to exist after W and M and C, so I'll put a dot to clarify. I have to use the given HTML format and make sure all line breaks are retained. I'm also paying close attention to punctuation. The "recd" abbreviation is a standard contraction for "received", I am good to put this in as is. The word "deadbeatism" does look strange, but it is accurate. The word is `recd` with a lower-cased 'd' with a hint of a period. The phrase `Gov. Brown` does have a period. Is the period inside the quotes? I check. The punctuation after the quote looks like "gentleman" - . There are two quotes inside the sentence. This word is in the middle. The context clues point towards an abbreviation. So, I think I have it. I need to make a transcription: ```html [Header]

[1883, May 22]
3

I was not aware of his last
feat until I recd your letter.
He is certainly a weird
apotheosis of deadbeatism.
Will he get a place in the
University after his book
on sheep culture in Asia?
Gov

[1882?]
May 22

Moreover I am without a
single personal acquaintance
on the Board of Regents.
Could I see you I could
make up my mind - some
things I want to say - that
it would not be prudent to write
I must see you before you go
North - Will you go to Tyler?

The withdrawal of the O.M. from
the political arena surprises
me much. What can it mean?
Timeo Danaos et dona ferentes.
I hope to see Judge Henry of
Dallas our next Gov. He is one
of the purest & strongest men
in the State - My first choice
of course would be Hubbard -
but he adheres to his determination
to keep aloof from State politics.
How I dread the next months
work! What is Prof. H. doing now?
Write me any chance you
get -

Your friend
Hand

[Margin: P.S. Just before mailing this scrawl, I see that Dr. Rambaut is in Austin. Where are the Eagles gathered together? Suppose he is University prospecting - Was told he was Prof of Lat & Greek at Geo, when I was at College - Heavy timber may be looked for - for Pres. of Univ. on Rams back at present J T H]

**My approach here is quite methodical.** I start by dissecting the request. I need to act as a transcriptionist, focusing on accuracy, handwriting interpretation, layout preservation, and specific HTML tags. The constraint is to only provide the transcribed text.

I then move on to analyzing the image. I see a handwritten letter with some interesting elements: vertical text in the top margin, a pencil-written date, and the main body text. The handwriting is a cursive style.
